--- Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@...> wrote:
> Yeah, you could certainly consider this an
> open-ended domain, but I don't
> think you'll have any more capacity for unbounded
> complexification.
> 100x100 Go is not any harder (well, relatively
> speaking) than 19x19 Go,
> its just the same strategy streched over a larger
> area. 

I don't know if anybody's done any theoretical work in
this area, but it's an interesting question.  As I
said, I've heard that 5x5 Go is *qualitatively*
different from 19x19 Go, but I could easily believe,
if it were true, that this would be due to the use of
edges and corners in forming eyes.  

You might be right, that 101x101 Go is not
qualitatively different from 19x19 Go, since the
larger the board grows, the less the edges and corner
probably play in strategy.  I don't know how
significantly the strategy would change as the board
size grows.

> This is the kind of problem I want to address with
> modular NE. Some
> domains are solvable by NE for small sizes, but they
> are scalable, which
> makes traditional NE infeasible after a certain
> point. If we could analyze
> the basic patterns that make up the solution, we
> could figure out how to
> replicate them correctly so that the NE solution is
> scalable.

Right.  It's definitely a problem that's going to need
working out to solve larger, more complicated domains.
 Talking with Ken, he seems well aware that the
current implementation of NEAT just isn't going to be
adequate when dealing with high input/output domains.

Derek
